sen.j: 能の特徴は数多いが、中でも重要なのは「死者」が能の中心となっているという点である。
sen.e: Noh has a lot of features, among which an especially important feature is that "dead" plays a central role in the Noh.

sen.j: 八世観世銕之丞は能の大きな特徴として「死者の世界からものを見る」という根本的な構造を指摘している。
sen.e: Tetsunojo KANZE VIII pointed out as a main feature of Noh that the fundamental structure is "the perspective from the world of the dead."

sen.j: すなわち、能においては多くの場合、亡霊や神仙、鬼といった超自然的な存在が主役（シテ）であり、常に生身の人間である脇役（ワキ）が彼らの話を聞き出すという構造を持っているのである。
sen.e: In other words, many Noh plays have some supernatural creatures such as ghosts, fairies or demons, etc. as the protagonist (Shite), and the play structure is mostly the supporting player (Nohwaki), who is often a flesh-and-blood character, finds out their stories by questioning. Concerning this, Tetsunojo has attributed a reason of this structure to the fact that Sarugaku (literally "monkey music", a form of Japanese theatre performing art resembling circus performance, popular in Japan during the 11th to 14th centuries)was compiled by Kan-ami, Zeami, Zenchiku KOMPARU et al during the Muromachi period, a chaotic war era during which death was extremely close to people.

sen.j: 柳田国男の論を受けた渡辺保によれば、「踊り」が飛躍や跳躍を含む語であるのに対し、「舞」は「まわる」つまり円運動を意味する語であり、そこに能の舞の特色があるとされる。
sen.e: According to Tamotsu WATANABE who accepted Kunio YANAGIDA's theory, while the word "Dance" contains leap and jump, the word "dance" in Noh means "turn", or in other words "rotary motion"; a characteristic of Noh dance.

sen.j: 能の舞の特徴は、極端な摺り足と独特の身体の構え、そして円運動である。
sen.e: The features of Noh dance are the excessive sliding of one's feet along, the peculiar posturing of one's body, and the rotary motions.

sen.e: The sliding feet is a peculiar stepping or walking way where the soles are slipped along the stage surface without raising the heels. (Especially, this is called hakobi.) sen.e: Each of the two leather skins is mounted on the front and back (horse leather covers a ring of plastron) and is secured with hemp yarn (called "adjusting string (sirabeo)").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理

sen.j: 左手で調緒を持ち、右肩にかついで右手で打つ。
sen.e: Hold the adjusting string with the left hand, keep the drum in the right shoulder and strike it with the right hand. According to how the adjusting string is gripped, where on the leather is struck, and how strong the strike is, there are four kinds of sounds (named as "chi", "ta", "pu" and "po").

Hold the adjusting string with the left hand, keep the drum on the right shoulder and strike it with the right hand. Depending upon how the adjusting string is gripped, where drum head is struck, and how strong the strike is, it will play one of four sounds (called as "chi", "ta", "pu" and "po").
Hold the adjusting string with the left hand, keep the drum on the right shoulder and strike it with the right hand.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置一原文一訳文の例外処理

sen.j: 調緒のしぼり方、革を打つ位置、打ち方の強弱によって4種類の音（チ、タ、プ、ポ、という名前がつけられている）を打ちわける。
sen.e: Depending upon how the adjusting string is gripped, where drum head is struck, and how strong the strike is, it will play one of four sounds (called as"chi," "ta," "pu" and "po").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理

sen.j: 演奏にはつねに適度な湿気が必要で、革に息をかけたり、裏革に張ってある調子紙（和紙の小片）を唾でぬらしたりして調節する。
sen.e: Since moderate moisture is always necessary for the performance, breath is put on leather and the tune paper (Choshigami, a small piece of Japanese paper mounted on the back leather) is adjusted by wetting with saliva.

Since some moisture is always necessary for the performance, the artist breathes on the leather and the tuning paper (Choshigami, a small piece of Japanese paper mounted on the back of the leather) is adjusted by wetting with saliva.

Since some moisture is always necessary for the performance, the artist breathes on the leather and the tuning paper (Choshigami, a small piece of Japanese paper mounted on the back of the leather) is adjusted by wetting with saliva.

sen.j: 大鼓（おおつづみ）
sen.e: Big drum
Big drum
Big drum

sen.j: 大鼓は、小鼓と区別するために大皮とも呼ばれるが、材質、構造はほぼ小鼓に等しく、全体的にひとまわり大きい。
sen.e: Though the big drum is called "a large skin" to distinguish from the small hand drum, the material and the structure are almost the same as the small hand drum; only the size is bigger overall.
Though the big drum is called "a large skin" to distinguish it from the small hand drum, the material and the construction are almost the same as the small hand drum; only the size is bigger overall.

Although the big drum is called "a large skin" to distinguish it from the small hand drum, the material and the construction are almost the same as the small hand drum; only the size is bigger overall.

sen.j: 左手で持って左膝に置き、右手を横に差し出して強く打ちこむ。
sen.e: Hold it with the left hand and put it on the left knee. Use the right hand to strike it sideways strongly.
Hold it with the left hand and put it on the left knee and use the right hand to strongly strike it sideways.
Hold it with the left hand and put it on the left knee and use the right hand to strongly strike it sideways.

sen.j: 音の打ちわけはほぼ小鼓と同様だが、音色の種類は小鼓より少ない。
sen.e: Though the striking sound is almost similar to the small hand drum, the types of tone are less than those of the small hand drum.
Though the striking sound is almost similar to the small hand drum, the types different tones are less than those of the small hand drum.
Although the striking sound is almost similar to the small hand drum, the types of different tones are less than those of the small hand drum.
sen.cmt: ofを追加Though →Although に変更しました。

sen.j: 型ぶりに反して全体に小鼓より高く澄んだ音を出す。
sen.e: Unexpected for its size and shape, the sound emitted is clearer and higher than a small hand drum in general.
Surprisingly for its size and shape, the sound emitted is clearer and higher than the small hand drum.
Surprisingly for its size and shape, the sound emitted is clearer and higher than the small hand drum.

sen.j: 湿気を極度に嫌うので、革は演奏の前に炭火にかざして乾燥させる必要がある。
sen.e: Because moisture is extremely a nuisance, the leather should be dried in the charcoal fire before the performance.
Because moisture is an extreme nuisance, the leather should be dried over a charcoal fire before the performance.
Because moisture is an extreme nuisance, the leather should be dried over a charcoal fire before the performance.

sen.j: 太く長い調緒を使って張りつめた皮を素手で打つのは大変痛いので、中指や薬指に「指皮」をはめ、掌（てのひら）に「当て皮」をつける。
sen.e: Because it is very painful to hit with bare-hand the skin mounted with the thick, long hemp rope, "finger leather (Yubikawa)" are put onto the middle finger and the ring finger. And "palm leather (Ategawa)" is put onto the palm.

Because it is very painful to hit with a bare-hand leather mounted with the thick, long hemp rope, "finger leather (Yubikawa)" are worn on the middle finger and the ring finger with "leather (Ategawa)" placed on the palm.

Because it is very painful to hit with a bare-hand leather mounted with the thick, long hemp rope, "finger leather (Yubikawa)" are worn on the middle finger and the ring finger with "leather (Ategawa)" placed on the palm.

sen.j: 唱歌（しょうが：音の口真似）は「ツ」「チョン」「ドン」の三種類。
sen.e: There are three kinds of singings (Mimicry of sound); "Tsu", "Chon", and "Don".
There are three kinds of songs (Mimicry of sound); "Tsu," "Chon," and "Don."
There are three kinds of songs (Mimicry of sound); "Tsu," "Chon," and "Don."

sen.j: 本来大鼓は小鼓の連調から発展してきた楽器であるといわれ、初期には鼓方の若手が大鼓にまわって小鼓の伴奏をしたのではないかと考えられている。
sen.e: It is said that the big drum was originally a musical instrument developed from the small hand drum. In fact, it is wondered that in the old days, the young drummers moved around to the big drums in order to play accompaniment for the small hand drums.

It is said that the big drum was originally a musical instrument that evolved from the small hand drum. In fact, there is speculation that in the old days, the young drummers moved around to the big drums in order to play accompaniment for the small hand drums.

It is said that a big drum was originally a musical instrument that evolved from a small hand drum and in early days it is thought that younger drummers accompanied the small hand drums by playing the big drums.
sen.cmt: 「鼓方の若手が大鼓にまわって」の「まわって」は「担当して」という意味ですので、内容を変更しました。

sen.j: そのため、大鼓の流儀は小鼓のそれから派生したもので、同流の小鼓が打ちやすいように手（譜）が考慮されている。
sen.e: Therefore, the striking style of the big drum is derived from that of the small hand drum. The hand (score) is considered in order that the small hand drum of the same striking style can be struck easily.
Therefore, the striking style of the big drum is derived from that of the small hand drum and the hand (score) is considered to be the same striking style and can be struck easily.

Therefore, the striking style of the big drum is derived from that of the small hand drum and the hand (score) is carefully written so that when accompanying the small drums, it is easier for small drums to strike.
sen.cmt: 原文から推測すると、大鼓の譜は小鼓と一緒に演奏したときに、小鼓が打ちやすいように考慮されている、ということだと思います。

sen.j: 太鼓
sen.e: Side drum
Side drum
Side drum

sen.j: 太鼓は、いわゆる締太鼓のことで、構造は基本的に鼓とかわらない。
sen.e: The side drum, or the so-called "tighten side drum", has a structure basically the same as a hand drum.
The side drum, or the so-called "tight side drum," has basically the same structure as the hand drum.
The side drum, or the so-called "tight side drum," has basically the same structure as the hand drum.

sen.j: 革は牛革で、撥の当たる部分に補強用の鹿革を貼ることが多い。
sen.e: The leather used is bull leather. However, the part struck with the plectra is reinforced often by pasting a deerskin.
The leather used is bull leather and the part struck with the plectra is reinforced often by laminating deerskin.
The leather used is bull leather and the part struck with the plectra is reinforced often by laminating deerskin.

sen.j: 撥は2本で、太鼓を台に載せて床に置き（この台を左吉台という）、正座した体の前で打つ。
sen.e: There are 2 plectra. The side drum is mounted on a stand (called hidarikichidai) put on the floor. The side drum is struck in front of the body sat upright.
There are 2 plectra and the side drum is mounted on a stand (called hidarikichidai) put on the floor and the side drum is struck in front of the body sitting upright.
There are 2 plectra and the side drum is mounted on a stand (called hidarikichidai) put on the floor and the side drum is struck in front of the body sitting upright.

sen.j: 音は響かせない小さな音（押さえる撥・ツクツク）と響かせる大きな音（小の撥、中の撥、大の撥、肩の撥・テンテン）の2種で、四拍子のリズムを主導する役割を担う。
sen.e: There are two types of sounds; the small sound that doesn't ring out (the plectrum is held and it sounds like tsukutsuku), and the big sound that rings out (small plectrum, medium plectrum, big plectrum, or shoulder plectrum is used, and it sounds like "tenten"). It plays the role of initiating the four-beat-rhythm.

There are two types of sounds which initiates a four-beat-rhythm; the weaker sound that doesn't ring out (the plectrum is held and it sounds like tsukutsuku), and the louder sound that rings out (small plectrum, medium plectrum, big plectrum, or shoulder plectrum is used, and it sounds like "tenten").

There are two types of sounds which initiates a four-beat-rhythm; the weaker sound that doesn't ring out (the plectrum is held and it sounds like tsukutsuku), and the louder sound that rings out (small plectrum, medium plectrum, big plectrum, or shoulder plectrum is used, and it sounds like "tenten").

sen.j: 太鼓が入るのは基本的に死者の霊や鬼畜の登場する怪異的な内容の曲のみで、そのほかの場合には笛と大小の鼓のみで演じる（この場合には大鼓がリズムの主導役を担う）。
sen.e: Basically, the side drum enters only during a grotesque scene where a departed spirit or a devil appears. Otherwise, only flutes, big and small hand drums are performed (with the big drum plays the initiation role of rhythm).

Basically, the side drum is played only during a grotesque scene when a departed spirit or a devil appears and apart from that, only flutes and big and small hand drums are used (with the big drum initiating the rhythm).

Basically, the side drum is played only during a grotesque scene when a departed spirit or a devil appears and apart from that, only flutes and big and small hand drums are used (with the big drum initiating the rhythm).

sen.j: 前者を「太鼓もの（太鼓入りもの、四拍子もの）」、後者を「大小もの」と呼んで区別する。
sen.e: To distinguish the 2 types of scenes, the former is called "side drum scene (Otuzumimono or Otuzumiirimono)" or "four-beat-rhythm (Yonbyoshimono or Shibyoshimono)", while the latter is called "big-and-small-drum scene (Daishomono)".

To distinguish the 2 types of scenes, the former is called "side drum scene (Otuzumimono or Otuzumiirimono)" or "four-beat-rhythm (Yonbyoshimono or Shibyoshimono)", while the latter is called "big-and-small-drum scene (Daishomono)".

To distinguish the 2 types of scenes, the former is called "side drum scene (Otuzumimono or Otuzumiirimono)" or "four-beat-rhythm (Yonbyoshimono or Shibyoshimono)", while the latter is called "big-and-small-drum scene (Daishomono)".

sen.j: 以上のほかに、舞台上でシテが鉦鼓（しょうこ）を鳴らす場合もある（『隅田川 (能)』『三井寺』）。
sen.e: Besides the above-mentioned, occasionally the protagonist (Shite) hits a gong drum (shouko) on the stage ('Sumida-gawa River (Noh)' and 'Mii-dera Temple').
Besides the above-mentioned, occasionally the protagonist (Shite) hits a gong drum (shouko) on the stage ('Sumida-gawa River (Noh)' and 'Mii-dera Temple').
Besides the above-mentioned, occasionally the protagonist (Shite) hits a gong drum (shoko) on the stage ('Sumida-gawa River (Noh)' and 'Mii-dera Temple').

sen.j: 多くは鐘の音や念仏の鉦鼓の音を表現するためだが、この場合もやみくもに打つのではなく、決まった譜がある。
sen.e: Mostly, the purpose is to express the sound of bell or gong from a prayer to the Buddha. However in this case, the drum is not struck at random. Rather, there is a decided score.
Mostly, the purpose is to express the sound of a bell or gong from a prayer to the Buddha but in this case, the drum is not struck at random and rather, there is a decided score.
Mostly, the purpose is to express the sound of a bell or gong from a prayer to the Buddha but in this case, the drum is not struck at random and rather, there is a decided score.

sen.j: また新作能においては、これら囃子方以外の音楽家が背景音楽の演奏に加わることもある（「伽羅沙」でのキリスト教の賛美歌やパイプオルガンなど）
sen.e: Moreover, in those new work of Noh, musicians other than these Noh musical bands occasionally join the performance of the backup tune. (In the Noh play "garasha", Christianity hymn and pipe organ etc are used.)
Moreover, in modern Noh, musicians other than Noh occasionally join the performance for background music (In the Noh play "garasha", Christian hymns and pipe organs, etc are used).
Moreover, in modern Noh, musicians other than Noh occasionally join the performance for background music (In the Noh play "garasha", Christian hymns and pipe organs, etc are used).

sen.j: 型
sen.e: Form
Form
Form

sen.j: 能は型（演技等の様式、パターン）によって構成されている。
sen.e: Noh is composed of forms (style and pattern of the performing techniques).
Noh is composed of various forms (style and patterns of the performing techniques).
Noh is composed of various forms (style and patterns of the performing techniques).

sen.j: 舞、所作、謡、囃子、全てに多様な型がある。
sen.e: Noh dance, Noh posturing, Noh chant, Noh musical band, and in fact everything in Noh, have various forms.
Noh dancing, Noh posturing, Noh chanting, Noh music, and in fact everything in Noh, has various forms.
Noh dancing, Noh posturing, Noh chanting, Noh music, and in fact everything in Noh, has various forms.

sen.j: これらの型の成立の経緯についてははっきりしないが、前出の梅若猶彦は型の出現を江戸期、型が安定的に継承されるようになったのは昭和期ではないかと推測している。
sen.e: The details of the establishment of these forms are not clear. However, UMEWAKA mentioned above infers and wonders if forms first appeared during Edo Period, became succeeded and stabilized during Showa Period.

The details of how these forms were established are not clear but UMEWAKA, as mentioned above, wondered if the forms that first appeared during Edo Period, evolved and became stabilized during the Showa Period.

The details of how these forms were established are not clear but UMEWAKA, as mentioned above, wondered if the forms that first appeared during Edo Period, evolved and became stabilized during the Showa Period.

sen.j: 型が出現した理由として梅若は、身体動作に名前を付けることで学習が効率的になるということを挙げている。
sen.e: As for the reason why the form appeared, UMEWAKA quoted the fact that study becomes efficient with names attached to the bodily movements.
As for the reason why this form appeared, UMEWAKA quoted the fact that study achieves efficiency by attaching names to the bodily movements.
As for the reason why this form appeared, UMEWAKA quoted the fact that study achieves efficiency by attaching names to the bodily movements.

sen.j: また梅若は、現代の能においてはこれらの型が必要以上に重視され、一種の信仰の対象のようになっていることの弊害も指摘した。
sen.e: Moreover, UMEWAKA pointed out that, in modern Noh, these forms are unnecessarily valued too much to the harmful extent that it has become like the object of a kind of belief. As stated in Zeami's writing, not to look for a belief in the forms, the important thing is to acquire the ability that a performer can freely control the relation between the inside and the body. UMEWAKA pointed out that, to achieve this ability, it is impossible only by studying the forms.

Moreover, UMEWAKA pointed out that, in modern Noh, these forms are unnecessarily valued too much to the harmful extent that it has become like the object of a kind of belief. As stated in Zeami's writing, don't look for a belief in form, the important thing is to acquire the ability for a performer to freely control the relationship between the inside and the body. UMEWAKA pointed out that, it is impossible to achieve this only by studying form.
Moreover, UMEWAKA pointed out that, in modern Noh, these forms are unnecessarily valued too much to the harmful extent that it has become like the object of a kind of belief.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理

sen.j: また世阿弥の著述からは型への信仰は窺えないこと、重要なのは役者が自分の内面と身体の関係を自由にコントロールできる能力を身に付けることであり、型の学習のみではそれは不可能なことを指摘している。
sen.e: UMEWAKA also pointed out that in Zeami's writing, a belief in form is not mentioned, and the important thing is to acquire the ability for a performer to freely control the relationship between the inside and the body in which it is impossible to acquire by merely studying the form.

sen.e: The defeat of World War II brought to the Noh sector a major turning point.

sen.j: 戦災によって多くの能舞台が焼失した為、それまで流派ごとに分かれて演能を行っていた能楽師たちが、流派の違いを超えて焼け残った能舞台で共同で稽古を行いだしたのである。
sen.e: Because a lot of Noh stages were burnt down due to war damage, Noh musicians, who had been doing its own style of Noh performance exclusively of the other sects until then, became united together and began to practice jointly in the Noh stages that remained un-burnt.

sen.j: その為、若手の能楽師たちは他流派の優秀な能楽師からも教えを受けることが多くなり、大いに刺激を受けるようになった。

sen.j: 観世銕之丞家の次男であった観世栄夫は、この時、観世流と他流の身体論の違いに大きな衝撃を受けた。
sen.e: Hideo KANZE, the second son of Tetsunojo KANZE's family, received at this time a big impact from the differences in the body theories between Kanze Style and other sects. Consequentially, he transferred to Kita Style as an art apprentice and became an adopted son of Roppeita KITA. He introduced himself as Hideo GOTO.

sen.j: 能の流派は大和四座の系統の流派と、それ以外の日本各地の土着の能に分けられる。
sen.e: The sects in Noh can be divided in accordance with the system of Yamoto-shiza, and the local Noh sects in various places in Japan.

sen.j: 大和四座とは観世座、宝生座、金春座、金剛座であるが、更に江戸期に金剛座から分かれた喜多流の五つを併せて四座一流と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Yamoto-shiza (literally "The four theatres of Japan") are Kanze-za, Hosho-za, Komparu-za and Kongo-za. In addition, Kita Style was spun off from Kongo-za during Edo Period. They are collectively called Shiza Ichiryu (literally "four theatres, five styles").

Yamoto-shiza (literally "The four theatres of Japan") are Kanze-za, Hosho-za, Komparu-za, and Kongo-za. In addition, Kita Style was spun off from Kongo-za during the Edo Period. They are collectively called Shiza Ichiryu (literally "four theatres, five styles").

sen.j: 喜多流は金剛流より出、金春流の影響を受けつつ江戸期に生れた新興の一派であって、明治期にいたってほかの四流と同格とされた。
sen.e: Spun off from Kongo Style, Kita Style, which continued to receive influence from Komparu Style, was a new sect born in the Edo Period. During Meiji Period, Kita Style became the same status as the other four major styles.

Spun off from Kongo Style, Kita Style, which continued to receive influence from Komparu Style, was a new sect born in the Edo Period and during the Meiji Period, the Kita Style achieved the same status as the other four major styles.

sen.j: 喜多流は創流以来座付制度を取らず喜多座と呼ばれることはなかった。
sen.e: Since its establishment, Kita Style has never adopted the system of "seat or theatre (za)" and never been called Kita Theatre. That is why people do not say "five theatres", but "four theatres, five styles".
